results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film follows the Penington family on a camping trip around Lake Eildon, Victoria, which starts and finishes in Melbourne. There are a number of staged scenes of the family and titles throughout informing where scenes are being taken.

The film begins with the title ‘Where my caravan has rested’ and follows with a map of Victoria drawing out the route taken.

Much of the trip shows scenes of different rivers including the Goulburn River, Delatite River, Jamieson River and Howqua River.

Places visited include Seymour, Alexandra, Rubicon, Eildon Weir, Jamieson, Woods Point and Mt Buller.

Much of the film is scenic and shows many scenes of flowering wattle trees. Beautiful distant scenes of Mt Buller and Mt Torbreck can be seen.

Of possible interest are scenes of the Rubicon Hydroelectric pipeline and power station and the Eildon Weir hydro power station.

The film ends with the garage doors closing on the Penington family car with the word ‘HOME’ revealed.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Where my Caravan has rested’
00:00:09:00 map showing the route taken for the holiday within the film
00:01:09:00 the Goulburn River, Seymour
00:01:54:00 Jocelyn Penington calling Margaret Penington to come out of a hollow tree
00:02:26:00 wattle tree blooms
00:02:38:00 scenes of Mt Torbreck
00:03:00:00 Rubicon Hydroelectric pipe line and power station
00:04:06:00 the Eildon Weir hydro power station
00:08:28:00 the Howqua River
00:09:01:00 child stares awkwardly at the camera while adult feeds some pigs
00:10:03:00 town of Jamieson with cars of the period
00:11:10:00 kookaburra on a fence
00:11:53:00 Dr Penington and Jocelyn fishing
00:13:18:00 the Poplar Hotel Wine and Spirits, Wood’s Point (now the Kevington Hotel)
00:15:56:00 a snow-capped Mt Buller
00:15:42:00 an old derelict watermill
00:15:52:00 Mt Buller
00:16:45:00 Jocelyn and Vivienne Penington kissing a snowman
00:16:50:00 Jocelyn and Vivienne Penington taken for a ride on a horse drawn sleigh
00:17:50:00 doors on the garage close to reveal the word ‘HOME’

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Easter celebrations at Green Hill]
results.brief_description:
This film shows Greek Easter celebrations, including a community BBQ, cooking lamb on a spit, music and dancing.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features a group of people picnicking on the banks of a river or lake wearing 1920s fashion and a dog fetching a stick in the water.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Most of this film shows a family enjoying the Falls Creek snowfields circa 1966/1967. There are also scenes of children playing in a Mirror or possibly a Sabot sailing boat dry-docked in a suburban back yard.

There are sequences of slalom ski events, chair lift and poma lift rides, and family leisure time spent inside the ski lodge.

We see ski races with slalom pole banners with “Molony Ski Shop” signage, and “Start” and “Finish” banners and flags with “Henke Schuhe” signage. A ski instructor wearing a red Parka teaching parallel turns. The old ski jump is visible down the valley.

A group of family and friends go down the Valley of the Moon ski run. A child navigates the tricky bits, then skis along the narrow raceline to the village. We see currawongs in the trees, a village, and return on the chairlift.

The filmmaker experiments with some in-camera slow-motion techniques, and amongst the crowd of onlookers and prize givers, we see people using what could be a Standard 8 camera or a 16mm Bolex camera, as well as 35mm SLR cameras.

There are some beautiful ski scenes filmed against blue skies amongst eucalypts and beside streams. A high shot provides an excellent view of the slalom course with flags and banners. We see a lovely panorama of green hills patched with snow in the background and views of the ski feild from the Snowhaven deck.

The film shows some great scenes of a man in charge of a “Snow mobile” as he starts it up and tows four skiers behind him. They traverse the beautiful snow-covered countryside in formation, across towards Mt McKay. Looking down over Sun Valley and a very long tow queue.

In a suburban backyard seemingly far from the snow fields, the film shows two children playing in a dry-docked Fireball sailing boat. We see the young boy strapped into the boat’s flying trapeze harness as he swings from the edge of the boat. The children play with a toy ambulance and ride down the street (Cleeve Court) on their bicycles. Along the street, we see vintage cars and suburban houses.

This film has good examples of ski fashion, winter snow fashion, snow vehicles, ski techniques, recreation, and leisure activities particular to the era.

The footage of the Falls Creek landscape is a good historical reflection of the topography of Falls Creek during the 60s. There are also good examples of a suburban street scape, children’s toys and sailing boats used for recreation.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00: 05:22:00 High shot of finish line, flags and skiers
00:13:47:00 Skiing alongside a stream
00:14:00:00 Skiers in single file navigate a narrow path
00:16:37:00 Women and children ski downhill towards the ski village
00:20:16:00 A young boy boards the poma tow
00:20:53:00 Children playing in Fireball sailing boat
00:23:05:00 Snow Cruiser driver starts the engine
00:23:57:00 Skiers in formation behind Snow Cruiser
00:25:20:00 Skiers single file behind Snow Cruiser

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Untitled Goose Game
results.credit_line:
Gift of House House Pty Ltd.
Acquired in collaboration with the Museum of Applied Sciences and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.material_description: Digital videogame and archive of material relating to the creation of Untitled Goose Game
results.brief_description: Untitled Goose Game is developed by Australian developer House House. Players take on the role of an annoying goose, waddling around an old English Town to create mischief and chaos. By completing a to-do list, players gradually unlock access to more areas of the town. Untitled Goose Game received widespread acclaim since its launched in late September 2019, with critics praising its gameplay and humour. It was named the D.I.C.E. Game of the Year and received a BAFTA Games Award for Best Family and Social game in 2020. It is available for PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, PC and Mac.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: It’s a lovely morning in the village and you are horrible goose. Untitled Goose Game is a slapstick-stealth-sandbox, where you are a goose let loose on an unsuspecting village. Make your way around town, from peoples’ back gardens to the high street shops to the village green, setting up pranks, stealing hats, honking a lot, and generally ruining everyone’s day.
description_for_label: Untitled Goose Game is developed by Australian developer House House. Players take on the role of an annoying goose, waddling around an old English Town to create mischief and chaos. By completing a to-do list, players gradually unlock access to more areas of the town. results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing
results.description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family ski trip to Falls Creek. We see the interior and exterior of the Winterhaven Ski Lodge and children being towed along by a ski tow. There are closeups and wide shots of skiers as they navigate their way around what appears to be a beginner’s ski run.

The film shows a children’s group ski lesson, a poma and T-bar lift, children skiing towards the camera and people being towed up the slope by the Village T-Bar ski tow. The children learn to ‘hop’ and the signal for ‘follow me’.

We see an adult couple preparing to ski with what appears to be a 1950s/1960s Volkswagen Beetle and pick-up truck parked in the background.

There are some lovely snow-covered landscapes of Falls Creek with people skiing in the sunshine against the backdrop of a bright blue sky.

A Snow Cat (vehicle) drives through the snow, passing ski lodges on the way.

A teenage boy runs beside a creek at the foot of a snow-covered embankment. We see a fishing expedition to the same creek, where fishing rods are prepared with bait and tackle, and two men and a boy cast their rods into the creek.

On the deck of Winterhaven Lodge, a group of people wearing shorts, swimwear and sunglasses lie on sun lounges enjoying the winter sun with the snow-covered embankment behind them. A woman wearing a bikini lies on a sun lounge beside her male companion who smokes and reads a book. Both are sporting 1960s sunglasses in the winter sun. We see a view from the deck of the ski lodge, showing snow-covered hills and surrounding ski lodges below.

The final section of the film follows a lone skier as he traverses his way down an empty slope.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, swimwear and sunglasses worn in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek landscapes in this film are also a great reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Film title: “Falls Creek 1962”
00:03:20:00 Father and son in tandem being pulled together on a tow rope
00:09:37:00 Ski School lesson with children
00:09:54:00 Man and woman preparing to ski with Volkswagen Beetle and c1950s pick-up truck parked in the background. Good fashion and vehicle example here
00:11:06:00 Wide shot of four skiers skiing down a slope
00:19:28:00 High shot taken from ski lodge of boy with skis with a snow-covered sunbed in the background
00:19:35:00 Vintage Snow Cat (vehicle) travels through the snow with dogs following, passing ski lodges along the way
00:22:06:00 Skiers and the landscape of Falls Creek
00:22:23:00 Snow and creek vista
00:22:45:00 Boy playing beside creek in the snow
00:23:54:00 Creek snow fishing expedition
00:25:48:00 People lounging in sun beds at the ski lodge, dressed in shorts, swimwear and sunglasses
00:26:02:00 View from the deck of the ski lodge showing snow-covered hills and lodges below
00:26:10:00 Woman lying on sun lounge wearing a bikini and eating an orange
00:26:21:00 Man lying on sun lounge smoking and reading a book
00:26:51:00 View of snow-covered hills and lodges
00:27:28:00 A lone skier skis down an empty slope

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows an aviation day in a field, with an aeroplane surrounded by spectators and a truck with the word ‘Shell’ parked next to it.
